topics.title: Introduction and Background
topics.summary: Lenny introduces Nilan Peiris (CPO of Wise) and frames the episode around Wise’s unusually high word-of-mouth growth (~70%). Nilan tees up the core idea: recommendation requires delivering an experience users didn’t think was possible.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor messages for Pendo (product-led platform) and Wix Studio (agency web platform).

topics.title: Wise overview: products, scale, and economics
topics.summary: Nilan explains Wise’s mission (cross-border money movement) and its three products (transfers, accounts, enterprise). He shares scale metrics ($12B/month, 30–40% YoY growth, ~0.65% avg fee, profitable with ~20% EBITDA) and highlights 70% word-of-mouth acquisition.

topics.title: Measuring word of mouth attribution
topics.summary: They discuss how Wise measures word of mouth using a blend of attribution modeling (cookies/referrers) and directly asking customers inside the onboarding flow. Lenny notes Airbnb used a similarly simple approach: just ask users how they heard about you.

topics.title: Why Wise prioritized word of mouth early
topics.summary: Nilan explains why WOM mattered: money transfer is a commodity with thin margins, making paid marketing harder and expensive brand-building less viable. This pushed Wise to seek scalable, low-distribution-cost growth channels.

topics.title: Using NPS as a proxy for recommendation
topics.summary: Nilan describes how Wise used NPS to understand and drive recommendation, finding invite and conversion rates rise dramatically as NPS scores increase (especially 7–10). He argues improving NPS can increase the “viral coefficient” of the customer base more than incremental conversion-rate tweaks.

topics.title: Product pillars: price, speed, ease of use
topics.summary: From NPS comments and customer feedback, Wise distilled the main drivers of advocacy into three pillars: cheaper, faster, easier. Nilan notes WOM only really kicked in when Wise was dramatically cheaper (e.g., 8–10x), not just slightly better than alternatives.

topics.title: Trust: hard to market, easier via friends
topics.summary: They explore trust as a barrier in financial services: landing-page trust signals help, but friend recommendations are far stronger. Nilan argues delivering a great experience that people share is a shortcut to solving many trust problems.

topics.title: Blowing users’ socks off to earn 9–10 NPS
topics.summary: Nilan explains that teams often stop at “it works,” but recommendation requires a step-change experience users didn’t know was possible. For Wise, that meant tackling deep infrastructure constraints to make transfers near-instant and radically cheaper, pushing NPS to ~70.

topics.title: Common WOM mistake: shortcuts vs 10x product
topics.summary: Nilan warns against taking infrastructure shortcuts to enter markets quickly because it won’t create hockey-stick WOM growth. Instead, Wise works backward from theoretical minimum cost and maximum speed, making bigger bets over longer horizons to reach 10x improvements.

topics.title: Airbnb parallels: working backward from the ideal
topics.summary: Lenny shares Airbnb examples of ideal-state thinking (Pixar storyboard journey, shift to instant booking) as a way to create step-change improvements. Nilan agrees and transitions into how Wise achieved similar step changes, especially on price.

topics.title: How Wise drove prices down profitably
topics.summary: Nilan explains Wise’s cost-to-transaction allocation model: every cost is attributed back to routes/customers, enabling pricing that covers true costs while lowering prices for most users. He breaks transaction costs into people/ops, risk (FX), and partner fees, and describes engineering efforts to reduce each.

topics.title: Singapore EKYC story: 10x convenience and advocacy
topics.summary: Wise faced a requirement to verify every customer face-to-face in Singapore, which was costly and disliked. By enduring the pain and channeling customer frustration into regulatory change, Wise helped secure an EKYC license (selfie + ID), creating a dramatically better experience that fueled WOM.

topics.title: Mission-driven sharing and customer-led growth flywheel
topics.summary: Nilan distinguishes rational drivers (price/speed/ease) from emotional drivers (mission authenticity). He recounts a mission email that users forwarded widely despite lacking marketing CTAs, and argues Wise operates from a single prioritized list: what makes customers happy also drives growth and shareholder value.

topics.title: Conviction over constant A/B testing
topics.summary: They discuss when to rely on experiments versus building conviction from customer insight and strategy (e.g., always passing cost savings to users). Nilan shares Wise’s view that you can’t “split test your way to love,” while still using measurement to detect breakage and understand impact.

topics.title: Sponsor Break
topics.summary: Sponsor message for Masterworks (art investing platform) and offer link for skipping the waitlist.

topics.title: Trusting teams, bold bets, and SEO example
topics.summary: Nilan describes encouraging teams to ship ideas leaders may doubt, while still measuring outcomes via analysis or tests. He begins an example about building a dedicated currency converter to capture high-intent SEO traffic and funnel users into Wise.
